thread.title: Tesla, Xoom shares jump; Western Union, Yelp drop
thread.title_full: Tesla, Xoom shares jump; Western Union, Yelp drop - MarketWatch

author: By     Wallace Witkowski   and   Victor Reklaitis
title: Tesla, Xoom shares jump; Western Union, Yelp drop
text:
Here are stocks seeing active trade on Thursday:
Gainers: Shares of digital-payments company Xoom Corp. XOOM, +21.01% surged more than 20% after attracting a buyout bid from Paypal Inc. EBAY, +2.36% late Wednesday. Western Union Co. WU, -6.87% shares dropped 5% after a Citigroup analyst said that PayPal’s acquisition of Xoom was bad news for Western Union .
Tesla Motors Inc. TSLA, +4.04% shares gained after the electric-car maker said it delivered a record number of Model S vehicles in the second quarter.
Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. VRTX, +4.02% shares were halted, but up 3.7%, after the Boston Globe reported that the biotech received marketing approval for a cystic fibrosis treatment.
Health Net Inc. HNT, +10.01% shares jumped after Centene Corp. CNC, -7.99% said it will buy Health Net in a cash-and-stock deal valued at about $6.8 billion. Centene shares fell 6%. Shares of Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. CTSH, -2.56% shares also declined as the company said it needed to defer the start of a seven-year services agreement with Health Net while the deal is being reviewed.
Progress Software Corp. PRGS, +6.22% surged after the business-software company late Wednesday raised its outlook for the year following better-than-expected earnings.
Decliners: Yelp Inc. YELP, -10.04% shares fell more than 10% following a report that the consumer-review website has stalled the process for a possible sale .
International Speedway Corp. ISCA, -6.57% shares dipped after the company’s quarterly profit and revenue came in below Wall Street’s expectations , according to a Briefing.com report.
NiSource Inc. NI, -4.87% shares declined after the utility completed its spin off Columbia Pipeline Partners LP CPPL, +1.62%
Tickers to Watch: Barnes & Noble Inc. BKS, +0.97% as it prepares to split up its business, said Sears Canada Inc. SCC, -1.32% Chief Executive Ronald D. Boire will lead its retail business , while current Chief Executive Michael P. Huseby will become executive chairman of its college books spinoff.
